column22: and many others.We were so afraid that our frogs wouldn't like the froggery better than any other place in the brook that we gave them all the pleasures we could think of. They always had plenty of fat juicy flies and water-bugs for their dinners
column23: and after a while we put some silver shiners and tiny minnows into the pool
column24: so that they would have fishes to play with as well as other frogs. You know you do not always like to play with other children; sometimes you like kittens and dogs and birds better.Then we gave our frogs little vacations once in a while. We tied a long soft woolen string very gently round one of their hind legs
column25: fastened it to a twig of one of the alderbushes
column26: and let them take a long swim and make calls on all their friends.We had a singing-school for them once a week. It was very troublesome
column27: for they didn't like to stand in line a bit
column28: and it is quite useless to try and teach a class in singing unless the scholars will stand in a row or keep in some sort of order. We used to put a nice little board across the pool
column29: and then try to get the frogs to sit quietly in line during their lesson. The General behaved quite nicely
column30: and really got into the spirit of the thing
column31: so that he was a splendid example for the head of the class. Then we used to put Myron W. Whitney next in line
column32: on account of his beautiful bass voice. We named him after a gentleman who had once sung in our church
column33: and I hope if he ever heard of it he didn't mind
column34: for the frog was really a credit to him. Myron W. Whitney behaved nearly as well as the General
column35: but we could never get him to sing unless we held the class just before bedtime
column36: and then the little frogs were so sleepy that they kept tumbling out of the singing-school into the pool. That was the trouble with them all; they never could quite see the difference between school and pool. It seems to me they must have known it was very slight after all.Towards the end of the summer we had trained them so well that once in a long while we could actually get them all still at once
column37: and all facing the right way as they sat upon that board. Oh! it was a beautiful sight
column38: and worth any amount of trouble and work! Twenty-one frogs in a row
column39: all in fresh green suits
column40: with clean white shirt fronts
column41: washed every day. The General and Myron W. Whitney always looked as if they were bursting with pride
column42: and as they were too fat and lazy to move
column43: we could generally count upon their good behavior.We thought that if we could only get them to look down into the pool
column44: which made such a lovely looking-glass
column45: and just see for once what a beautiful picture they made
column46: --sitting so straight and still
column47: and all so nicely graded as to size
column48: --they would like it better and do it a little more willingly.We thought
column49: too
column50: the baby frogs would be ashamed
column51: when they looked in the glass
column52: to see that while the big frogs stayed still of their own free will
column53: THEY had to be held down with forked sticks. But we could never discover that they were ashamed.

column1: So when everything was complete my little sister used to “let go” of the baby frogs (for
column2: as I said
column3: she had to hold them down while we were forming the line)
column4: and I would begin the lesson. Sometimes they would listen a minute
column5: and then they would begin their pranks. They would insist on playing leap-frog
column6: which is a very nice game
column7: but not appropriate for school. Tiny Tim would jump from the foot of the class straight over all the others on to Myron W. Whitney's back. Baby Mine would try to get between Croaker and Goldilegs
column8: where there wasn't any room. Nimblefoot would twist round on the board and turn his back to me
column9: which was very impolite
column10: as I was the teacher. Finally
column11: Hop-o'-my-Thumb would go splash into the pool
column12: and all the rest
column13: save the good old General
column14: would follow him
column15: and the lesson would end. I suppose you have heard frogs singing just after sunset
column16: when you were going to bed? Some people think the big bull-frogs say
column17: “JUGO'RUM! JUGO'RUM! JUGO'RUM!” But I don't think this is at all likely
column18: as the frogs never drink anything but water in their whole lives.We used to think that some of the frogs said
column19: “KERCHUG! KERCHUG!” and that the largest one said
column20: “GOTACRUMB! GOTACRUMB! GOTACRUMB!” Perhaps you can't make it sound right
column21: but if you listen to the frogs you can very soon do it.We thought the frogs in our froggery the very best singers in all the country round. After our mother had tucked us in our little beds and kissed us good-night
column22: she used to open the window
column23: that we might hear the chirping and humming and kerchugging of our frogs down in the dear old garden.We bring flowers and vines to hang about his picture
column24: we sing the songs and play the games he loved the best
column25: and we remember the story of his life. We thank him all day long; for he made the kindergarten for us
column26: he invented these pretty things that children love to do
column27: he thought about all the pleasant work and pleasant play that make the kindergarten such a happy place.On this very day

column29: the baby Froebel came to his happy father and mother. He was a little German baby
column30: like Elsa's brother and Fritz's little sister
column31: and when he began to talk his first words were German ones.But the dear mother did not stay long with her little Friedrich
column32: for she died when he was not a year old
column33: and he was left a very sad and lonely baby. His father was a busy minister
column34: who had sermons to write
column35: and sick people to see
column36: and unhappy people to comfort
column37: from one end of the week to the other
column38: and he had no time to attend to his little son; so Friedrich was left to the housemaid
column39: who was too busy herself to care for him properly. She was often so hurried that she was obliged to shut him up in a room alone
column40: to keep him out of her way
column41: and then it was very hard work for the child to amuse himself.The only window in this room looked out on a church that workmen were repairing
column42: and Friedrich often watched these men
column43: and tried to do just as they did. He took all the small pieces of furniture
column44: and piled one on top of the other to make a big
column45: big church
column46: like the one outside; but the chairs and stools did not fit each other very well
column47: and soon the church would come tumbling about his head. When Froebel grew to be a man
column48: he remembered this
column49: and made the building blocks for us
column50: so that we might make fine
column51: tall churches and houses as often as we liked.Rebel's home was surrounded by other buildings
column52: and was close to the great church I told you about. There were fences and hedges all around the house
column53: and at the back there were sloping fields
column54: stretching up a high hill.When the little boy grew old enough to walk
column55: he played in the garden alone
column56: a great deal of the time; but he was not allowed to go outside at all
column57: and never could get even a glimpse of the world beyond. He could only see the blue sky overhead
column58: and feel the fresh wind blowing from the hills.
